text: What if we changed the C++ in the reference implementation of Julia to Rust?

elements.text: What if we changed the C++ in the reference implementation of Julia to Rust?

text:
The only C++ in Julia is for the LLVM codegen.
And it is specifically there because only the C++ library for LLVM is complete.

elements.text:

text: Ohhhh OK, Nevermind!

text:
Most of the non-julia parts of Julia are C. and I guess you could   it with rust, though making that play nice with `ccall` is nontrivial,
and it's still redoing work which could be spent doing something more important

text: <@U012FH66MFW> probably stupid suggestion here, but as a potential benefit it occurred to me  ... how about leveraging Rust's borrow checker for Julia instead of the GC? ... not even sure whether this can be done and/or how

elements.text: probably stupid suggestion here, but as a potential benefit it occurred to me  ... how about leveraging Rust's borrow checker for Julia instead of the GC? ... not even sure whether this can be done and/or how

text: No, that would require a drastic language change, and it is independent of how and in what language the runtime is implemented

elements.text: No, that would require a drastic language change, and it is independent of how and in what language the runtime is implemented

text: No worries, it's important to think about what are language semantics and what are runtime implementation details

text: I know that Rust semantics to allow the borrow checker are a bit cumbersome. However, was thinking that perhaps some meta-programming could help here ... again, not sure how

elements.text: I know that Rust semantics to allow the borrow checker are a bit cumbersome. However, was thinking that perhaps some meta-programming could help here ... again, not sure how

text: Rust borrow checker forces a programmer to think about ownership of memory and mutability

elements.text: Rust borrow checker forces a programmer to think about ownership of memory and mutability

text: A GC frees the programmer from worrying about ownership

elements.text: A GC frees the programmer from worrying about ownership

text: well ... yes and no, when you want to just write something quick the GC frees you from that, that is true. However, when you want to optimize your code for performance you need to start thinking which part of your code is allocating or not, and how to reuse your allocated arrays or not. Also, for multi-threading you also must think about immutability and allocations as well. If you are already doing this, perhaps you can as well introduce some extra macros that give you access to a borrow checker.

elements.text: well ... yes and no, when you want to just write something quick the GC frees you from that, that is true. However, when you want to optimize your code for performance you need to start thinking which part of your code is allocating or not, and how to reuse your allocated arrays or not. Also, for multi-threading you also must think about immutability and allocations as well. If you are already doing this, perhaps you can as well introduce some extra macros that give you access to a borrow checker.

text: but was thinking that that's the main advantage of using Rust (the borrow checker) and one pain point of Julia is optimizing memory and/or real time performance which the borrow checker could solve.

elements.text: but was thinking that that's the main advantage of using Rust (the borrow checker) and one pain point of Julia is optimizing memory and/or real time performance which the borrow checker could solve.

text: Language design is about choosing a point in the design space and trading off benefits and downsides. Rust borrow-checker is innovative and cool. Part of Julia's appeal is it's ease of use and the capability to successively fine tune and focus on performance. So yes in the areas where you really care about performance you have to think about allocations, etc...

elements.text: Language design is about choosing a point in the design space and trading off benefits and downsides. Rust borrow-checker is innovative and cool.
